Chris Grossack (they/them) said:

are dramatically different over F2\mathbb{F}_2F2​, but they're isomorphic over Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​ for all primes ≠2\neq 2=2, since in those fields 222 is invertible.

This was kind of my point earlier! Here's a proof theoretic angle, which might convince you,

By the way, it's not that I was unconvinced by what you wrote earlier: I just failed to understand it, mainly because I wanted to see a simple example of some nonisomorphic schemes over Z\mathbb{Z}Z that become isomorphic over Q\mathbb{Q}Q, and you seemed to instead be giving me a suggestion for how to prove that such examples must exist. I didn't want to think about that: I wanted to just snatch an example out of thin air, because it seemed so obvious that they must exist. I was like those students who say, when you're telling them how to work a problem, "but what's the answer?"

If XXX has two presentations over Q\mathbb{Q}Q, then there should be a proof of this fact (by which I mean something like a sequence of Tietze transformations but for ring presentations). But any such proof is finitely long, so one only has to divide finitely many times. But then the same proof will work over any Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​ with ppp large enough for all those divisions to be allowed!

That's nice. This sounds like it can become a proof of some nice general theorem.

By the way, remember the stuff about "models" - that is, ways to choose a scheme over Z\mathbb{Z}Z that gives some chosen scheme over Q\mathbb{Q}Q? And the stuff about "Neron models" - that is, initial models?

I'm guessing that while this affine scheme over Q\mathbb{Q}Q

⟨u,v∣u2+v2=1⟩ \langle u,v \vert u^2 + v^2 = 1 \rangle ⟨u,v∣u2+v2=1⟩

has lots of models

Xa,b=⟨x,y∣a2x2+b2y2=1⟩ X_{a,b} = \langle x, y \vert a^2 x^2 + b^2 y^2 = 1 \rangleXa,b​=⟨x,y∣a2x2+b2y2=1⟩

namely one for each a,b∈Za,b \in \mathbb{Z} a,b∈Z, the model X1,1X_{1,1}X1,1​ is a Neron model. The point is that we have a map

X1,1→Xa,b X_{1,1} \to X_{a,b} X1,1​→Xa,b​

sending xxx to axaxax and yyy to bybyby, but usually this is not invertible since we're not allowed to divide by aaa and bbb.

If X1,1X_{1,1}X1,1​ is really a Neron model, it would be nice because it says the circle x2+y2=1x^2 + y^2 = 1x2+y2=1 is "better" than the other ellipses Xa,bX_{a,b}Xa,b​ in some objective sense. But I'm actually not at all sure it's correct.

Chris Grossack (they/them) said:

As an aside, I can't actually find anything on "Tietze transformations for algebra presentations"... Surely someone has studied that, though! Does it have a different name?

I don't know. I think there should be a general theory of Tietze moves going between all different finite presentations of any finitely presented algebra in any variety (in the universal algebra sense of 'variety'). It should look a lot like the familiar case of Tietze moves for group presentations. It should be in some book on universal algebra.

Now let me try to work out the Hasse-Weil zeta functions of these schemes over Z\mathbb{Z}Z:

A=⟨x,y∣x2+y2=1⟩ A = \langle x,y \vert x^2 + y^2 = 1 \rangle A=⟨x,y∣x2+y2=1⟩

and

B=⟨x,y∣x2+4y2=1⟩ B = \langle x, y \vert x^2 + 4 y^2 = 1 \rangle B=⟨x,y∣x2+4y2=1⟩

I've never seen anyone do this, probably because it's too elementary. But it will help me understand the more fancy stuff in Calegari's paper.
In each case the zeta function will be a product of 'Euler factors', one for each prime.

Let's do AAA first. The Euler factor for the prime ppp is

Zp(A,s)=exp⁡∑n>0∣A(Fpn)∣np−ns\displaystyle{ Z_p(A, s) = \exp \sum_{n > 0} \frac{\vert A(\mathbb{F}_{p^n})\vert }{n} p^{-ns} } Zp​(A,s)=expn>0∑​n∣A(Fpn​)∣​p−ns

where A(Fpn)A(\mathbb{F_{p^n}})A(Fpn​) is the set of points of our scheme over the field with pnp^npn elements.
This formula probably looks a bit horrible (at least to category theorists) but there's a fairly elegant conceptual explanation, which I will only give on request.

So what's ∣A(Fpn)∣\vert A(\mathbb{F}_{p^n})\vert ∣A(Fpn​)∣? It's the number of solutions of

x2+y2=1x^2 + y^2 = 1x2+y2=1

where x,y∈Fpnx,y \in \mathbb{F}_{p^n}x,y∈Fpn​.
How many solutions are there? I'm guessing that - at least for most primes ppp - there are pn+1p^n + 1pn+1.

The reason I'm guessing this is that at least over R\mathbb{R}R the 'quadric' x2+y2=1x^2 + y^2 = 1x2+y2=1 is isomorphic to the projective line, which is an ordinary line and a point at infinity. We can see this using stereographic projection.
But over Fpn\mathbb{F}_{p^n}Fpn​ the projective line has pn+1p^n + 1pn+1 elements.

Let me check this guess in the case where it's most likely to be wrong: p=2p = 2p=2. (The prime 2 is bad news in general, and especially for polynomials of degree 2, e.g. the derivative of x2x^2x2 is zero in a field of characteristic 2.)
So, in F2\mathbb{F}_2F2​ the solutions of x2+y2=1x^2 + y^2 = 1x2+y2=1 are (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) and (1,0)(1,0)(1,0), so there are just two, not 3 as I was predicting.
(It's possible that I'm getting in trouble because I'm working with an affine quadric instead of a projective one, or it could be that the prime 2 is doing its usual evil things.)
In F3\mathbb{F}_3F3​ we get solutions (0,±1)(0,\pm 1)(0,±1) and (±1,0)(\pm 1, 0)(±1,0) and no others (right?). So we are getting 4 solutions, as I predicted.

(You may wonder why in this category theory discussion group I'm taking every question and exploring it by means of the most mundane calculations possible, rather than simply hitting it with a well-chosen functor or using a short exact sequence or something. It's because I want to become familiar with algebraic geometry from the ground up: if I don't even understand the solutions of x2+y2=1x^2 + y^2 = 1x2+y2=1 over a finite field how can I claim to know anything about the subject?)

In F5\mathbb{F}_5F5​ we have numbers 0,±1,±20, \pm 1, \pm 20,±1,±2, with (±2)2=−1(\pm 2)^2 = -1(±2)2=−1, so the solutions of x2+y2=1x^2 + y^2 = 1x2+y2=1 are (0,±1),(±1,0)(0,\pm 1), (\pm 1, 0)(0,±1),(±1,0) and... that's all??? Just 4 solutions again???

Okay, so either I'm making computational mistakes or I don't understand the pattern at all. Now I'm guessing the pattern may be related to p mod 4 p \bmod 4pmod4, since −1-1−1 has a square root in Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​ iff p=1 mod 4p = 1 \bmod 4p=1mod4 (except for the annoying case p=2 p = 2p=2).

I'm sure you're interested in doing this computation yourself, but I actually did it a few years ago for exactly the same reason as you! I find it impossible to learn things like this without computing. Though I used sage to try every possible solution over finite fields both to speed things up and to make sure I didn't miss any!
If you want to cheat at all, you can find it in this pdf: https://grossack.site/assets/docs/weil-conjectures-talk/paper.pdf

I was going to write a blog post going into these kinds of computations in more detail (and explaining how the Weil conjectures themselves are REALLY concrete numerical predictions! It's only the proofs that are fearsome)... But it looks like I never got around to writing it, and by now I've forgotten a lot of things

Chris Grossack (they/them) said:

If you want to cheat at all, you can find it in this pdf: https://grossack.site/assets/docs/weil-conjectures-talk/paper.pdf

I was considering cheating, because I was getting a bit tired and my predictions weren't panning out very well. But now I'm remembering some more theoretical stuff that may help me guess the answers, or at least motivate me to persevere. It's in Gilles and Szamuely's book Central Simple Algebras and Galois Cohomology, which is a great introduction to Galois descent through some concrete examples - namely, the classification of central simple algebras, which is actually how Noether, Hasse and Brauer stumbled into the cohomology of groups!

Among the easiest of the central simple algebras are the 'quaternion algebras', which are precisely the 4-dimensional simple algebras over a field whose center is that field - or more concretely, algebras over a field with generators i,ji, ji,j and relations

i2=a,j2=b,ij=−ji i^2 = a, j^2 = b, ij = -ji i2=a,j2=b,ij=−ji

For example all quaternion algebras over R\mathbb{R}R are isomorphic to the quaternions (take a=b=−1a = b = -1a=b=−1 for example) or the algebra of 2 ×\times× 2 real matrices (take a=b=1a = b = 1a=b=1 for example).
And Brauer and Severi noticed that any quaternion algebra gives a projective curve called a 'conic', which is defined by quadratic equations.
So my rather feeble attempt to count points on what I was calling 'quadrics' is actually connected to the classification of conics and thence to quaternion algebras and thence to Galois descent!
Let me try to say a bit more about this - by now I'm fired up and don't mind talking to myself.

We can write elements of any quaternion algebra as

w1+xi+yj+zk w 1 + x i + y j + z k w1+xi+yj+zk

where w,x,y,zw,x,y,zw,x,y,z are elements of the field it's over, 111 is the unit of the quaternion algebra, and k=ijk = i jk=ij.

So, our quaternion algebra has a 3d space of imaginary elements:

{xi+yj+zk} \{ x i + y j + z k \} {xi+yj+zk}

The square of an imaginary element is always real - I think it equals this:

(xi+yj+zk)2=ax2+by2−abz2 (x i + y j + z k)^2 = ax^2 + by^2 - ab z^2 (xi+yj+zk)2=ax2+by2−abz2
And this is a homogeneous quadratic polynomial on F3\mathbb{F}^3F3, where F\mathbb{F}F is our (hitherto nameless) field.
So it defines a curve in the projective plane over F\mathbb{F}F, called a conic.

Concretely this curve consists of triples (x,y,z)(x,y,z)(x,y,z) with

ax2+by2−abz2=0 ax^2 + by^2 - abz^2 = 0ax2+by2−abz2=0

modulo rescaling.
We can define conics over any field to be curves in the projective plane defined by nontrivial homogeneous quadratic equations... I hope that's the right definition....

And there was a witty guy named Witte, who showed this:

Theorem. Isomorphism classes of quaternion algebras correspond bijectively to isomorphism classes of conics.
(This should really be an equivalence of categories.)
There's more: we can classify both these things using Galois cohomology.
But now I have to go hear Scottish folk music at my local pub!
Hmm, this is project is sprawling outwards in some ways that will be frustrating to anyone reading this. Let me summarize where I am right now.

I was trying to compute the Hasse-Weil zeta functions of these affine schemes over Z\mathbb{Z}Z:

A=⟨x,y∣x2+y2=1⟩ A = \langle x,y \vert x^2 + y^2 = 1 \rangle A=⟨x,y∣x2+y2=1⟩

and

B=⟨x,y∣x2+4y2=1⟩ B = \langle x, y \vert x^2 + 4 y^2 = 1 \rangle B=⟨x,y∣x2+4y2=1⟩

Don't be intimidated: this simply amounts to counting the number of solutions of these equations over all finite fields Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​. (There's a unique finite field of size qqq for each prime power q=pnq = p^nq=pn.)

Since these are quadratic equations, this should not be extremely hard. People have done it for similar-looking cubic equations, as part of "computing the Hasse-Weil zeta function of an elliptic curve". This is supposed to be much easier.

However, it's better to work with projective varieties than affine varieties - that'll let us use more theorems. So now, for each finite field Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​, I want to count the number of nonzero solutions of

x2+y2=z2x^2 + y^2 = z^2 x2+y2=z2

modulo rescaling, i.e. counting the solutions (x,y,z)(x,y,z)(x,y,z) and (ax,ay,az)(ax,ay,az)(ax,ay,az) as the same for any a≠0a \ne 0a=0.

This new improved equation is homogeneous: the rescaling of any solution is another solution. The variable zzz is called a homogenizing variable - it replaces the constant 111 I had before, and makes the equation homogeneous.

The solutions of this new improved equation, mod rescaling, are points in a projective variety I'll call A′A'A′.

Similarly I want to count the points in a projective variety I'll call B′B'B′ coming from the equation

x2+4y2=z2 x^2 + 4y^2 = z^2x2+4y2=z2

I'll call this variety B'.

Projective varieties of this sort, given by a single homogeneous quadratic equation in 3 variables, are extremely famous: they're called conics. They've been studied intensively since 200 BC by a host of people including Apollonius of Perga, Kepler, Descartes, Fermat, and many more modern algebraic geometers, so I'm not trying to do anything new.

Why switch to the projective setting? In their book Central Simple Algebras and Galois Cohomology, Gille and Szamuely mention a result:

It is a well-known fact from algebraic geometry that a smooth projective conic defined over a field k is isomorphic to the projective line P1\mathrm{P}^1P1 over k if and only if it has a k-rational point.
I think "has a k-rational point" simply means the homogeneous quadratic equation describing our conic has a nonzero solution in the field k. (If I'm wrong someone please correct me.)

If I'm right about this, the conic A', coming from

x2+y2=z2x^2 + y^2 = z^2 x2+y2=z2

has a k-rational point when k=F2k = \mathbb{F}_2k=F2​, e.g. x = 1, y = 0, z = 1. So, it must be isomorphic to the projective line over F2\mathbb{F}_2F2​. So, it should have 3 points.

And it does have 3 points! The nonzero solutions of x2+y2=z2x^2 + y^2 = z^2x2+y2=z2 are

(x,y,z)=(1,0,1),(0,1,1),(1,1,0)(x,y,z) = (1,0,1), (0,1,1), (1,1,0)(x,y,z)=(1,0,1),(0,1,1),(1,1,0)

and rescaling does nothing in F2\mathbb{F}_2F2​, so we get 3 points.
The weird one is the so-called "point at infinity", where the homogenenizing variable zzz is zero.

If we were working over the real numbers, the equation x2+y2=z2x^2 + y^2 = z^2x2+y2=z2 wouldn't have a nonzero solution with z=0z = 0z=0. The corresponding projective variety (nonzero solutions mod rescaling) would be simply the circle! So I'm just saying the ordinary circle doesn't have a point at infinity.
But the hyperbola does have a point at infinity, as you can see by looking at x2−y2=z2x^2 - y^2 = z^2x2−y2=z2: it has exactly one nonzero real solution mod rescaling with z=0z = 0z=0.

Over F2\mathbb{F}_2F2​ we have 1 = -1, so the circle and the hyperbola are the same! So it might have been touch-and-go whether the circle over F2\mathbb{F}_2F2​ has a point at infinity or not... but it does.

Anyway, using the sledgehammer provided by Gille and Szamuely, we instantly see the conic A' has q+1q + 1q+1 points over the finite field Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​ if it has a "rational k-point" for k = Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​.
And I'm hoping this means A' has q+1q+1q+1 points if x2+y2=z2x^2 + y^2 = z^2x2+y2=z2 has any nonzero solutions over Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​.
But it always does, namely x = 1, y = 0, z = 1.

John Baez said:

The solutions of this new improved equation, mod rescaling, are points in a projective variety I'll call A′A'A′.

Similarly I want to count the points in a projective variety I'll call B′B'B′ coming from the equation

x2+4x2=z2 x^2 + 4x^2 = z^2x2+4x2=z2

I'll call this variety B'.

4x^2 is a typo
Thanks - fixed!

So, it looks like our projective conic A', given by

x2+y2=z2 x^2 + y^2 = z^2x2+y2=z2

is maximally boring: over every finite field it's isomorphic to the projective line! All the 'trickiness' I was bumping into earlier comes from working with the affine conic

x2+y2=1 x^2 + y^2 = 1x2+y2=1

which leave out points at infinity (namely nonzero solutions with z=0z = 0z=0).

So here's what I was actually seeing:

  • over F2\mathbb{F}_2F2​ our projective conic A' does contain a point at infinity, namely (1,1,0)(1,1,0)(1,1,0) so the affine version was missing a point, so x2+y2=1 x^2 + y^2 = 1x2+y2=1 had just 2 solutions (x=1,y=0x = 1, y = 0x=1,y=0 and x=0,y=1x = 0, y = 1x=0,y=1) instead of the full 3 points we expect from the projective line over F3\mathbb{F}_3F3​.

  • over F3\mathbb{F}_3F3​ our projective conic A' does not contain a point at infinity, so all the points lie in affine space, so x2+y2=1 x^2 + y^2 = 1x2+y2=1 has 4 solutions (x=±1,y=±1x = \pm 1, y = \pm 1x=±1,y=±1) which is just the right number to be all the points in the projective line over F3\mathbb{F}_3F3​.

and so on.

Let me do just one more, to show they get a bit weirder:

  • Over F5\mathbb{F}_5F5​ our projective conic A′A'A′ conic contains two points at infinity. There are plenty of solutions of x2+y2=z2x^2 + y^2 = z^2x2+y2=z2 with z=0z = 0z=0, each of which gives a point at infinity in our conic, namely (±2,±1,0)(\pm 2, \pm 1, 0)(±2,±1,0) and (±1,±2,0)(\pm 1, \pm 2, 0)(±1,±2,0). That's 8 solutions! But points in our conic are solutions mod rescaling and F4\mathbb{F}_4F4​ has 4 nonzero elements so we really just get 8/4 = 2 points at infinity in our conic. The are more points in our conic that are not points at infinity, coming from these other 16 solutions of x2+y2=z2x^2 + y^2 = z^2x2+y2=z2: (±1,0,±1),(\pm 1, 0, \pm 1),(±1,0,±1), (±2,0,±2),(0,±1,±1), (\pm 2, 0, \pm 2), (0, \pm 1, \pm 1),(±2,0,±2),(0,±1,±1), (0,±2,±2) (0, \pm 2, \pm 2)(0,±2,±2). These give 16/4 = 4 points in our conic that are not points at infinity. So we get 6 points in our conic, which is just the right number to be all the points in the projective line over F5\mathbb{F}_5F5​.

This funny business confirms what they've been telling us at least since 1822, namely that projective varieties are better behaved than affine varieties! Using the sledgehammer of Gille and Szamuely's result, we know the projective conic x2+y2=z2x^2 + y^2 = z^2x2+y2=z2 over some field Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​ is isomorphic to the projective line over that field if it has a point, which it always does (namely (1,0,1)). So computing its Hasse-Weil zeta function is a snap!

First we calculate the local zeta function at each prime ppp. Since we're calling this conic A′A'A′ and it has pk+1p^k + 1pk+1 points over Fpk\mathbb{F}_{p^k}Fpk​, we have

Zp(A′,s)=exp⁡(∑k=1∞∣A′(Fpk)∣kp−ks) Z_p(A',s) = \exp \left( \sum_{k = 1}^\infty \frac{|A'(\mathbb{F}_{p^k})|}{k} p^{-k s} \right) Zp​(A′,s)=exp(∑k=1∞​k∣A′(Fpk​)∣​p−ks)

=exp⁡(∑k=1∞pk+1kp−ks) = \exp \left( \sum_{k = 1}^\infty \frac{p^k + 1}{k} p^{-k s} \right) =exp(∑k=1∞​kpk+1​p−ks)

=exp⁡(∑k=1∞pkkp−ks)exp⁡(∑k=1∞1kp−ks) = \exp \left( \sum_{k = 1}^\infty \frac{p^k}{k} p^{-k s} \right) \exp \left( \sum_{k = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{k} p^{-k s} \right) =exp(∑k=1∞​kpk​p−ks)exp(∑k=1∞​k1​p−ks)

What's going on? A′A'A′ is the projective line, and it's a disjoint union of an affine line with pkp^kpk points over Fpk\mathbb{F}_{p^k}Fpk​ and a single point. Local zeta functions multiply under disjoint unions, and the two factors here are the local zeta function of the affine line and the local zeta function of a point!

Let's work out the second factor, which is the local zeta function of a point:

Zp(point,s)=exp⁡(∑k=1∞1kp−ks) Z_p(\mathrm{point}, s) = \exp \left( \sum_{k = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{k} p^{-k s} \right) Zp​(point,s)=exp(∑k=1∞​k1​p−ks)

Remember

∑k=1∞xkk=−ln⁡(1−x) \sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{x^k}{k} = -\ln(1-x) ∑k=1∞​kxk​=−ln(1−x)

so

∑k=1∞1kp−ks=−ln⁡(1−p−s) \sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{k} p^{-ks} = -\ln(1-p^{-s}) ∑k=1∞​k1​p−ks=−ln(1−p−s)

so

Zp(point,s)=exp⁡(∑k=1∞1kp−ks)=exp⁡(−ln⁡(1−p−s)) Z_p(\mathrm{point}, s) = \exp \left( \sum_{k = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{k} p^{-k s} \right) = \exp(-\ln(1-p^{-s})) Zp​(point,s)=exp(∑k=1∞​k1​p−ks)=exp(−ln(1−p−s))

so

Zp(point,s)=11−p−s \displaystyle{ Z_p(\mathrm{point}, s) = \frac{1}{1-p^{-s}} } Zp​(point,s)=1−p−s1​

The Weil Conjectures (now proved) say the poles and zeros of the local zeta function of a smooth projective variety over Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​ are determined by its etale cohomology groups. This local zeta function only has pole at 0, no zeros, and I think that's because the point has only 0th cohomology.

We can multiply all these local zeta functions, one for each prime, to get the Hasse-Weil zeta function of a point:

Z(point,s)=∏p11−p−s=ζ(s) \displaystyle{ Z(\mathrm{point}, s) = \prod_p \frac{1}{1 - p^{-s}} = \zeta(s) } Z(point,s)=p∏​1−p−s1​=ζ(s)

Yes, the Riemann zeta function! We're using the Euler product formula here.

Next we can work out the Hasse-Weil zeta function of the affine line:

Zp(affine line,s)=exp⁡(∑k=1∞pkkp−ks) Z_p(\textrm{affine line}, s) = \exp \left( \sum_{k = 1}^\infty \frac{p^k}{k} p^{-k s} \right) Zp​(affine line,s)=exp(∑k=1∞​kpk​p−ks)
=exp⁡(∑k=1∞1kp−k(s+1)) = \exp \left( \sum_{k = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{k} p^{-k (s+1)} \right) =exp(∑k=1∞​k1​p−k(s+1))

This is just what we got for the point, but with s+1s+1s+1 replacing sss, so

Zp(affine line,s)=11−p−(s+1) \displaystyle{ Z_p(\textrm{affine line}, s) = \frac{1}{1 - p^{-(s+1)}} }Zp​(affine line,s)=1−p−(s+1)1​

and multiplying all these local zeta functions we get the Hasse-Weil zeta function of the affine line:

Z(affine line,s)=∏p11−p−(s+1)=ζ(s+1) \displaystyle{ Z(\textrm{affine line}, s) = \prod_{p} \frac{1}{1 - p^{-(s+1)}} = \zeta(s+1) } Z(affine line,s)=p∏​1−p−(s+1)1​=ζ(s+1)

Remember we're trying to compute the local zeta functions of our conic A′A'A′, which is just projective line, and we know we can get these by multiplying those for the point and the affine line. Here's what we get for the local zeta functions:

Zp(A′,s)=Zp(point,s)Zp(affine line,s)=1(1−p−s)(1−p−s+1) \displaystyle{ Z_p(A', s) = Z_p(\mathrm{point},s) Z_p(\textrm{affine line}, s) = \frac{1}{(1 - p^{-s})(1 - p^{-s+1})} } Zp​(A′,s)=Zp​(point,s)Zp​(affine line,s)=(1−p−s)(1−p−s+1)1​

These have poles at s=0s = 0s=0 and s=1s = 1s=1, which the Weil Conjectures explain as coming from the two nonvanishing etale cohomology groups of the projective line.

Multiplying all these we get the Hasse-Weil zeta function:

Z(A′,s)=ζ(s)ζ(s+1) \displaystyle{ Z(A',s) = \zeta(s) \zeta(s+1)} Z(A′,s)=ζ(s)ζ(s+1)

But the point of this thread was supposed to be this. Two schemes X,YX, YX,Y over Z\mathbb{Z}Z can give isomorphic schemes over Q\mathbb{Q}Q. There's no reason to expect Z(X,s)=Z(Y,s)Z(X,s) = Z(Y,s)Z(X,s)=Z(Y,s). But some of you have argued convincingly that these two zeta functions are the same except for finitely many Euler factors, because XXX and YYY must agree "except over finitely many primes".

At this stage I'm just trying to see that happening in some simple examples. My plan is to compare the projective conic A′A'A′

x2+y2=z2 x^2 + y^2 = z^2x2+y2=z2

(which I have by now beaten to death) with another projective conic that's isomorphic over Q\mathbb{Q}Q. I originally wanted to use the projective conic B′B'B′ given by

x2+4y2=z2 x^2 + 4y^2 = z^2 x2+4y2=z2

This seemed likely to be nonisomorphic only at the prime 2.

Theorem. Points with rational coordinates are dense in the unit circle..

Slick Proof. Take the unit circle and draw a straight line from its top point (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) to any point a∈Qa \in \mathbb{Q}a∈Q on the xxx axis. Since this line hits the circle at one point with rational coordinates, it must hit the circle at another point (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) with rational coordinates! The reason is that if a quadratic equation with rational coefficients has one rational root, the other root must also be rational. Such lines hit the circle in a dense set of points. So points with rational coordinates are dense on the unit circle. \qquad █

Explicit Proof. The line hits the circle where x2+y2=1x^2 + y^2 = 1x2+y2=1 and also x=a(1−y)x = a(1 - y)x=a(1−y), so the points of intersection must have

a2(1−y)2+y2=1a^2(1-y)^2 + y^2 = 1a2(1−y)2+y2=1

a2−2a2y+a2y2+y2=1a^2 - 2a^2y + a^2y^2 + y^2 = 1a2−2a2y+a2y2+y2=1

(a2+1)y2−2a2y+(a2−1)=0(a^2+1)y^2 - 2a^2y + (a^2-1) = 0 (a2+1)y2−2a2y+(a2−1)=0

y2−(2a2/(a2+1))y+(a2−1)/(a2+1)=0y^2 - (2a^2/(a^2+1)) y + (a^2-1)/(a^2+1) = 0 y2−(2a2/(a2+1))y+(a2−1)/(a2+1)=0

We know y=1y = 1y=1 is a solution of this quadratic since our line crosses the circle at (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) - we don't have to check this!

Thus, Rogers' Lemma says that y=−1−by = -1 - by=−1−b is also a solution of the above quadratic, where bbb is the second coefficient of the quadratic. That is,

y=−1+2a2/(a2+1)=(a2−1)/(a2+1)y = -1 + 2a^2/(a^2+1) = (a^2-1)/(a^2+1) y=−1+2a2/(a2+1)=(a2−1)/(a2+1)

is also a solution. This gives

x=a(1−y)=2a/(a2+1)x = a(1-y) = 2a/(a^2 + 1)x=a(1−y)=2a/(a2+1)

Thus, for any number aaa,

(x,y)=(2a2/(a2+1),(a2−1)/(a2+1)) (x,y) = \big( 2a^2/(a^2+1), (a^2-1)/(a^2+1) \big) (x,y)=(2a2/(a2+1),(a2−1)/(a2+1))

is a point on the unit circle. And if aaa is rational this point has rational coordinates. These points are dense in the circle since rationals are dense in the line and the map

a↦(2a2/(a2+1),(a2−1)/(a2+1)) a \mapsto \big(2a^2/(a^2+1), (a^2-1)/(a^2+1) \big)a↦(2a2/(a2+1),(a2−1)/(a2+1))

from the line to the circle minus (1,0)(1,0)(1,0) is a homeomorphism. \qquad █

If we think of x2+y2=z2x^2 + y^2 = z^2x2+y2=z2 as defining a scheme over some field of characteristic 2, it's not a [[reduced scheme]] because the stalks have nontrivial nilpotents.
